data.title: Farnese last name popularity, history, and meaning
data.meta_description: Data on the popularity and origin of the last name Farnese in the United States based on the most recent Census data.
data.text:
Find out how popular the last name Farnese is in the United States and learn more about the meaning, history, and race and ethnic origin of people in America who are named Farnese.

Farnese, like all of the last names we have data for, is identified by the U.S. Census Bureau as a surname which has more than 100 occurrences in the United States in the Decennial Census survey. The most recent statistics we have for the Farnese surname is from the 2010 census data.

Popularity of Farnese in America

Farnese is the 98982nd most popular name in America based on the data we have collected from the U.S. Census Bureau.

The Farnese surname appeared 183 times in the 2010 census and if you were to sample 100,000 people in the United States, approximately 0 people would have the surname Farnese.

We can also compare 2010 data for Farnese to data from the previous census in 2000. The table below contains all of the statistics for both years in a side-by-side comparison.

The history of the last name Farnese

The surname Farnese originated in Italy during the medieval period. It is derived from the town of Farnese, which is located in the province of Viterbo, Lazio region. The name Farnese itself comes from the Latin word "Farnesio," meaning "belonging to Farnesius."

The Farnese family rose to prominence in the late 15th century. They were a powerful Italian noble family that played a significant role in the politics and culture of Renaissance Italy. One of the earliest recorded references to the name Farnese can be found in a document dating back to 1390, which mentions a certain Ranuccio Farnese.

In the 15th century, the Farnese family held several important positions in the Papal States. Alessandro Farnese (1468-1549) became Pope Paul III in 1534 and was a key figure during the Counter-Reformation. He is known for convening the Council of Trent and for his patronage of the arts, including the commissioning of works by Michelangelo and Titian.

Another notable member of the Farnese family was Alessandro Farnese (1545-1592), a prominent military leader and Duke of Parma and Piacenza. He was a skilled commander who served in the Spanish Netherlands during the Eighty Years' War against the Dutch Revolt.

The Farnese family also left a lasting legacy in the field of architecture. The Palazzo Farnese in Rome, which was built in the early 16th century, is a prime example of Renaissance architecture and is now home to the French Embassy in Italy.

Elisabetta Farnese (1692-1766) was a prominent figure in the 18th century. She was the Queen of Spain as the wife of King Philip V and played a significant role in the politics of her time, exerting influence over her husband and later her son, King Ferdinand VI.

Another notable individual with the surname Farnese was Ranuccio Farnese (1569-1622), who was a military leader and the seventh Duke of Parma and Piacenza. He was also the Governor of the Spanish Netherlands from 1615 to 1618.

Race and ethnic origin of people with the last name Farnese

We also have some data on the ancestry of people with the surname Farnese.

The below race categories are the modified race categories used in the Census Bureau's population estimates program. All people were categorized into six mutually exclusive racial and Hispanic origin groups:

White only

Black only

American Indian and Alaskan Native only

Asian and Pacific Islander only

Hispanic

Two or More Races

For the most recent 2010 census data, the race/ethnic origin breakdown for Farnese was:

Note: Any fields showing (S) means the data was suppressed for privacy so that the data does not in any way identify any specific individuals.

Since we have data from the previous census in 2000, we can also compare the values to see how the popularity of Farnese has changed in the 10 years between the two census surveys.

Data source

The last name data and ethnic breakdown of last names is sourced directly from the Decennial Census survey, conducted every 10 years by the United States Census Bureau.

The history and meaning of the name Farnese was researched and written by our team of onomatology and genealogy experts.

If you have a correction or suggestion to improve the history of Farnese, please contact us.

Reference this page

We spend a lot of resources downloading, cleaning, merging, and formatting the data that is shown on the site.

If you found the data or information on this page useful in your research, please use the tool below to properly cite or reference Name Census as the source. We appreciate your support!
